intro: Alsinanthus lateriflorus, commonly known as the side-flowered alsin, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Alsinanthus lateriflorus is often found in disturbed soils and is adapted to arid conditions.
